awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP: Materials and System Design for Thermal management in Asphalt Pavements Using Solar-Geothermal Energy
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Research Partnerships (PFI-RP) project is to advance a new cost-effective, safe, and sustainable technology to reduce the surface temperature variation for enhancing the safety, lifespan, and service quality of pavements. Asphalt pavements are damaged or degraded by strong summer sunlight or winter snow plows and salts/sands. The proposed architecture is such that in summer, heat is harvested and stored in geothermal wells to prevent road softening and rutting; in winter, the heat is pumped to the surface for ice/snow removal and low-temperature crack mitigation. This technology can be used in driveways, parking lots, highway ramps, and other surfaces, and in the longer term can be extended to other infrastructure surfaces, including building envelopes, airports, and bridges. This convergent approach to critical needs in civil infrastructure will also be extended into coursework for hybrid teaching, and the student recruitment and outreach program will promote STEM participation and entrepreneurial leadership from women and under-represented groups. 

The proposed project uses a heat exchange system to connect a pavement with a geothermal heat well to regulate the pavement surface temperature by the vast thermal mass of the earth. It integrates experimental mechanics, materials engineering, civil engineering, and fluid system design to evaluate: 1) seasonal heat storage and utilization through thermal management with bi-directional geothermal energy utilization; 2) the lifespan extension of pavement overlays because of the favorable temperature ranges; 3) material design and optimization for life-cycle performance improvement. The energy and mass transfer through the system with time will be simulated by the Green’s function technique and validated by experimentally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

PFI-RP: Material and System Design for Thermal Management in Asphalt Pavements Using Solar-Geothermal Energy

Project Outcomes Report (06/01/2020 - 05/31/2024 )

This project aimed to develop a novel pavement technology by an interdisciplinary research collaboration between 2 universities and 2 industrial partners. In lineage with on the previous fundamental research project CMMI 1301160 and ongoing I-Corps project IIP 1935773, this proposed asphalt pavement system uses solar and geothermal energies to regulate pavement surface temperature. In the course of market studies in the I-Corps program, the team proposed one pivot to shift the application of the solar-geothermal system from pavements to buildings. The team closely worked with the startup company PVT Clean Energy to develop the technology in material innovation, system integration and control, energy harvesting and management, which led to the following significant advancements in the state of the art of zero energy buildings:   

(i) Heat pipes are embedded into the wall panel for heat exchange with the indoor environment, which avoids leakage problems;

(ii) Phase change material (PCM) is used for heat-pipe based geothermal heat exchanger for extended heat exchange with the ground;

(iii) A passive heat exchanger connecting the top of the wall panel and the bottom of the geothermal wells, with the one-way flow controls to dissipate heat from the room to the ground, and flow back to the wall panel (the summer loop in the figure)

Key outcomes or achievements are summarized as follows: 1) The software package iBEM has been released for case studies in elastic, thermal, and Stokes’ flow analyses including static and transient analyses, which is available to the industry and research community as an open-source software. 2) The main results have been documented in the new book - Inclusion based boundary element method (iBEM), ISBN-13: 978-0128193846, which has been published and used as a textbook for PI’s course of Micromechanics of Composite Materials. 3) Over 30 papers have been published in referred journals, which attracted attentions and interest from industry and academia. 4) The team is forming research projects with industry collaborators including Schuco, ENGSOFT, and SPDL to solve their materials engineering and design problems. 5) This project also provided case studies to another book - Building Integrated Photovoltaic Thermal Systems: Fundamentals, Designs and Applications, ISBN-13: 978-0128210642. 6) The research results have been transferred to PVT Clean Energy from Columbia University through an agreement with Columbia Technology Ventures (CTV). 7) The startup company PVT Clean Energy is making breakthroughs on technology development and commercialization with SBIR and DOE funds (>$4M on contract) and looks forward to capital investment and large scale applications.

Overall, this project provided a solid foundation to establish the energy harvesting and thermal management technology for solar-geothermal energy buildings and will bring exciting opportunities for new fundamental research and many applications in building, greenhouse and other infrastructure.  



Last Modified: 09/16/2024
Modified by: Huiming Yin
